{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3530940,"name":"Carter Patterson","username":"Cartertheprogramer","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/8797f3/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T02:26:35.711Z","cooked":"

Hello, I am with team 5462, we just recently converted to using swerve drive instead of Differential Drive. In addition to this, we decided to begin using path planner. However, when using path planner our robots odometry and real life movements, do not align. For example, we created a path with path planner and are running using the autoSelector.getSelected. The auto we choose to follow is programmed to run one meter. Instead when we test, we only go 31in. When looking at the X and Y values printed by the odometry, it shows that we traveled one X value (One meter). In addition to this, when we change our kP value to 0 and run, we only get 27in. But our robots odometry still shows that we went one meter.

FYI, This program was taken from team 6081, and has been revised to fit the new 2025 WPI Library.

Our code, https://github.com/Carterprograms/2025-Competition-Code-main

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T02:26:35.711Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":13,"reads":112,"readers_count":111,"score":87.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":492116,"topic_slug":"path-planner-is-not-going-1-meter","display_username":"Carter Patterson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/Carterprograms/2025-Competition-Code-main","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":67493,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/path-planner-is-not-going-1-meter/492116/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3530946,"name":"Adithya Anand","username":"Adithya_Anand","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/adithya_anand/{size}/208753_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T02:30:28.696Z","cooked":"

Odometry will get off due to wheel slip. That’s what vision measurements are for with apriltags. Odometry relies on the gyro and measured wheel positions (dead-reckoning). The problem with dead reckoning is that wheels tend to slip (the wheel spinning when the robot is stationary, like when it hits an object or tries to accelerate faster than your wheels have traction). When this happens, the drivetrain has no method of correcting itself, and will only get worse throughout the match. Vision lets you correct for this issue, which is why it’s so critical for global pose estimation.

However, I’d take this with a grain of salt because with a movement as small as yours, odometry should be pretty accurate. Have you looked at decreasing your maximum acceleration and/or velocity? That could help increase traction and decrease slip.

I talked with some other people and they said that it was my wheel diameter that was wrong. We have not tunned our wheel COF yet, we have it set to 1 for testing.
